info.title: DASE Exchange APIs
info.description:
# Introduction

Welcome to the Documentation Site for DASE Exchange APIs!

DASE Exchange provides a robust platform for digital asset trading, and our APIs enable seamless
integration for traders and developers alike. Currently, we offer two types of APIs:

1. **REST API** - Intended for trading (placing and canceling orders), obtaining account information, and retrieving market data.
2. **Websocket API** - Intended for streaming real-time exchange data such as order book changes, recent trades, and orders.

## API URLs

| API type      | Production URL             |
| ------------- | -------------------------- |
| REST API      | <https://api.dase.com/v1>  |
| WebSocket API | <wss://ws-api.dase.com/v1> |

## Getting started

To get started quickly, follow these steps:

1. [Create a DASE account](/docs#description/creating-dase-account)
2. [Obtain a new API key](/docs#description/obtaining-api-keys)
3. [Create authenticated request](/docs#description/authentication)
4. [Submit the request to the API](/docs#sending-authenticated-request)

<span id="creating-dase-account" />

### Creating DASE account

Navigate to <https://www.dase.com/sign-up>. Use email & password combination or one of available
authentication providers.

<span id="obtaining-api-keys" />

### Obtaining API keys

To access the APIs, you need to obtain an API key. Follow these steps to get a new API key:

1. Log in to your account at https://www.dase.com/login
2. Navigate to customer support section https://www.dase.com/myaccount?section=support
3. Open a support ticket and describe how you want to use the API
4. After verification from our customer support team you will obtain `API_KEY_ID` and
   `API_KEY_SECRET`values

#### Important

> Keep your API key values safe and secure. Do not share it with anyone. Otherwise, your account may
> be compromised.

# Authentication

Most of REST-API endpoint require user authentication. To send API request you need follow these two
steps:

1. [Compute request signature](/docs#computing-request-signature)
2. [Send request with signature](/docs#sending-authenticated-request)

<span id="computing-request-signature" />

## Computing request signature

Request signature is generated using the _HMAC-SHA256_ algorithm. The signature is computed from
these fields:

1. **Unix timestamp** - Number of milliseconds since the Unix epoch, e.g. `1719307772417`
2. **Request method** - Should be specified in _upper case_, e.g. `GET`, `POST`, `DELETE`
3. **Request path** - Should also include query string parameters if any, e.g., `/v1/orders?status=open`
4. **Request body** (if any) - The body should be formatted the same way as it is sent in the request body. For `GET` requests, the body is an empty string.

The signature is computed as follows:

1. Concatenate the timestamp, request method, request path and request body into a single string in
    this order:

```
{timestamp}{request_method}{request_path}{request_body}
```

2. Compute the HMAC-SHA256 hash of the string using your API key secret as the key. Note that API
    key generated in the DASE dashboard is Base64-encoded and it might be needed to decode it into
    raw bytes depending on used hashing library.

### Example of signature generation

```rs
pub fn compute_signature(
  request_method: &str,
  request_path: &str,
  request_body: &str,
  timestamp: u128,
  secret_bytes: Vec<u8>,
) -> String {
  let message_to_sign = format!(
    "{}{}{}{}",
    timestamp,
    request_method.to_uppercase(),
    request_path,
    request_body
  );

  let mut hmac = Hmac::<Sha256>::new_from_slice(&secret_bytes).expect("Invalid HMAC secret key");
  hmac.update(message_to_sign.as_bytes());

  let signature = hmac.finalize().into_bytes();
  BASE_64.encode(signature)
}
```

### Example inputs and outputs

You can use these example values to verify that your signing algorithm works correctly:

```rs
// Input values
request_method: "GET"
request_path: "/v1/orders?status=open"
request_body: ""
timestamp: "1719325936838"
secret: "NbMBz+ZLqON9yc/tTA8+5eynWD/37pk6b5yq28q9yH99aJyz4fgifpN1wOv28ReSubHvcsT4Yaq8+c12XjArdg=="

// Expected output signature
signature: "t7y7D/gZgY+pEugfGN4GhEvZf9Cuee3fTQdDAl8s0rY="
```

<span id="sending-authenticated-request" />

## Sending authenticated request

To send authenticated request you need to include these headers with each request:

- `ex-api-key` - Your API key ID (UUID formatted key, e.g. `1cf7ba16-b6b6-435d-a781-62dcd9e99a00`)
- `ex-api-sign` - Request signature generated using your API key secret. See [Computing request signature](/docs#user-content-computing-request-signature) section.
- `ex-api-timestamp` - Unix timestamp in milliseconds (e.g. `1719307772417`). Your timestamp must be
  within 10 seconds of the API server time or your request is considered expired and rejected.

### Example of sending request

```rs
pub const API_BASE_URL: &str = "https://api.dase.com";

pub async fn send_signed_request(
  request_method: &str,
  request_path: &str,
  request_body: String,
  timestamp: u128,
  api_key_id: &str,
  signature: String,
) {
  let client = Client::new();
  let url = format!("{}{}", API_BASE_URL, request_path);
  let method = Method::from_str(request_method).expect("Invalid HTTP method");

  let response = client
    .request(method, url)
    .header("ex-api-key", api_key_id)
    .header("ex-api-sign", signature)
    .header("ex-api-timestamp", timestamp.to_string())
    .header("Content-Type", "application/json")
    .body(request_body)
    .send()
    .await
    .expect("Failed to send request");

  let status = response.status();
  let body = response.text().await.expect("Failed to read response body");

  dbg!(status, body);
}
```

# General Overview

## Rate Limits

The API enforces rate limits to prevent abuse and ensure fair usage.

The rate limit headers are returned in the response for each request:

- `x-ratelimit-limit`: The maximum number of requests allowed in the time interval
- `x-ratelimit-remaining`: The number of requests remaining in the current interval
- `x-ratelimit-used`: The number of requests already used in the current interval
- `x-ratelimit-reset`: The Unix timestamp when the rate limit resets
- `x-ratelimit-resource`: The resource path that the rate limit applies to

If a request exceeds the rate limit, a 429 Too Many Requests HTTP status is returned. Beware, that
rate limits may be changed over time and clients should not rely on specific values.

## Market Precision

Each market has a defined size and price precision that is enforced on all order placement requests.

To retrieve the precision for a market, use the `/v1/markets` or `/v1/markets/{market}` endpoints.
The response includes:

- `size_precision`: The maximum number of decimals allowed for order size
- `price_precision`: The maximum number of decimals allowed for order price

For example, if `size_precision` is `8` and `price_precision` is `2`, an order with size
`"0.00000001"` and price `"50000.00"` would be valid, but an order with size `"0.000000001"` or
price `"50000.001"` would be rejected due to invalid precision.

Note that currency precision may differ from market price precision. For example, some markets allow
clients to input EUR price with 4-decimal price precision, however, EUR ledger transactions
currently use 2-decimal precision. Here is the list of current currency precisions:

| Currency | Decimals |
| -------- | -------- |
| Eur      | 2        |
| Czk      | 2        |
| Ada      | 8        |
| Btc      | 8        |
| Doge     | 8        |
| Dot      | 8        |
| Eth      | 8        |
| Ltc      | 8        |
| Sol      | 8        |
| Usdc     | 8        |
| Usdt     | 8        |
| Xrp      | 8        |
| Atom     | 8        |
| Avax     | 8        |

## API Errors

The API uses the following error codes:

| Error                  | HTTP Status | Description                                            |
| ---------------------- | ----------- | ------------------------------------------------------ |
| `InternalError`        | 500         | An unexpected error occurred                           |
| `NotFound`             | 404         | The specified resource was not found                   |
| `InsufficientFunds`    | 400         | Insufficient funds to complete the request             |
| `InvalidInput`         | 400         | The request input is invalid                           |
| `InvalidIdFormat`      | 400         | The provided identifier is invalid                     |
| `InvalidNumberFormat`  | 400         | Invalid number format                                  |
| `Unauthorized`         | 401         | Authentication failed or missing credentials           |
| `Forbidden`            | 403         | The action is forbidden for the authenticated user     |
| `PayloadTooLarge`      | 413         | The request payload exceeds the maximum allowed size   |
| `ServiceStarting`      | 503         | The service is starting up                             |
| `ServiceRestarting`    | 503         | The service is restarting                              |
| `ServiceUnavailable`   | 503         | The service is currently unavailable                   |
| `ServiceReadOnly`      | 503         | The service is in read-only mode                       |
| `ServiceCancelOnly`    | 503         | The service only allows canceling orders               |
| `ServicePostOnly`      | 503         | The service only allows limit post_only orders         |
| `ServiceShuttingDown`  | 503         | The service is shutting down                           |
| `TooManyRequests`      | 429         | The request exceeds the rate limit                     |
| `MarketOrdersDisabled` | 400         | Market orders are not enabled for the specified market |

All error responses, except for `500 Internal Server Error`, include a JSON body with `type` and `message` fields:

```json
{
  "type": "<error_type>",
  "message": "<error_message>"
}
```

# WebSockets

To connect to the WebSocket service, use the following address: `wss://ws-api.dase.com/v1/`.
Once connected, the client must send a subscribe message within 10 seconds; otherwise, the server
will close the connection. Avoid sending duplicate subscription messages for the same channel.

## Authentication

Most of channels providing market data are public (don't require authentication). However, some
channels (e.g. `my-orders` channel) require authentication. To authenticate, you need to obtain a
JWT token through the REST API and include it in the WebSocket subscription message. To do so,
follow these steps:

1. Get a WebSocket token by calling the `https://api.dase.com/v1/auth/websocket` REST API endpoint.
2. Use the token when subscribing to authenticated channels like `my-orders`.

Note that the WebSocket JWT token must be used for subscription within 15 minutes window. After that,
the token expires and a new token must be obtained for new authenticated subscriptions.

## Timeouts

The server will close the connection if:

- No subscribe message is received within the timeout (10 seconds) after connecting
- No pong message is received within the timeout (10 seconds) when server sends health-check ping
  message. Usually, this is automatically handled by websocket libraries.

## Subscribing

Send a subscribe message within the timeout period after connecting. Subscription message can be sent
multiple times to subscribe to different channels.

Example Subscription message:

```json
{
  "type": "subscribe",
  "timestamp": 1718620709343,
  "params": {
    "channel": "l2-updates",
    "markets": ["BTC-EUR"],
    "snapshot": true
  }
}
```

Example Subscription message with authentication:

```json
{
  "type": "subscribe",
  "timestamp": 1718620709343,
  "params": {
    "channel": "my-orders",
    "markets": ["BTC-EUR"]
  },
  "auth": {
    "token": "eyJhbGci..."
  }
}
```

## Unsubscribing

Send an unsubscribe message when you want to stop listening to particular channels.

Example Unsubscribe message:

```json
{
  "type": "unsubscribe",
  "timestamp": 1718621334134,
  "params": {
    "channels": ["l2-updates"],
    "markets": ["BTC-EUR"]
  }
}
```

## Orderbook Snapshot Message

The orderbook snapshot message provides a complete view of the orderbook at a specific point in
time. This message is sent when a client subscribes to the `l2-updates` channel with the snapshot
parameter set to `true`.

## WebSocket Channels

### l2-updates

Provides real-time updates of the market order book. Each message contains a list of changes where
each change is a tuple of `[side, price, size]`. Note, that the `size` denotes the remaining size of
orders on the target price level.

E.g.

```
[["sell", "61435.2", "0.12963471"]]
```

means that the size of all sell orders with price `61435.2` is `0.12963471`.

If the size is `0`, it means that the price level should be removed from the order book. The
`sequence` field can be used to detect whether the client didn't miss any updates. Sequence is a
increasing number generated for each orderbook change.

Clients are encouraged to maintain a local copy of the order book. For one-time snapshot retrieval,
REST API endpoint `/v1/markets/{market}/snapshot` can be also used.

Example message:

```json
{
  "channel": "l2-updates",
  "market": "BTC-EUR",
  "payload": {
    "type": "l2update",
    "sequence": 4610125,
    "timestamp": 1718620710112.786,
    "changes": [["sell", "61435.2", "0.12963471"]]
  }
}
```

### ticker

Provides information about the latest trade and best prices on the market. Each message contains:

- `price` - The last traded price
- `size` - The size of the last trade
- `bid` - The best bid price
- `ask` - The best ask price

Example message:

```json
{
  "channel": "ticker",
  "market": "BTC-EUR",
  "payload": {
    "type": "ticker",
    "sequence": 4610125,
    "timestamp": 1718620710112.786,
    "price": "61435.2",
    "size": "0.12963471",
    "bid": "61430.0",
    "ask": "61440.0"
  }
}
```

### my-orders

Provides updates for the authenticated user's orders.

\*Requires authentication.

Example message:

```json
{
  "channel": "my-orders",
  "market": "BTC-EUR",
  "payload": {
    "id": "6ed3004f-d595-4663-940c-a47a7d6e7fb8",
    "client_id": "233becb9-7214-4538-9807-21892e087b05",
    "type": "limit",
    "side": "buy",
    "price": "61435.2",
    "size": "0.12963471",
    "filled_size": "0.12963471",
    "filled_cost": "7964.13",
    "status": "filled",
    "created_at": 1751622235746.853
  }
}
```

get.description:
This endpoint allows you to retrieve the current status and version of the API.

Example response:
```json
{
"version": "1.0.0"
}
```

Requires `user:trading:read` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve transactions associated with a specific account. It supports cursor-based pagination:
- `limit`: The maximum number of transactions to return (default is 100, range is 1 to 100).
- `before`: Cursor for pagination to get transactions before a specific transaction ID.

Requires `user:accounts:write` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve a WebSocket token for authenticating and authorizing WebSocket connections. The token includes permissions for reading trading data.

Requires `user:accounts:read` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve the balances for all currencies in the authenticated user's portfolio.

Requires `user:accounts:read` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve the balance for a specific currency in the authenticated user's portfolio.

This endpoint allows you to retrieve a list of all available markets and their configurations.

Example response:
```json
{
"markets": [
{
"market":"BTC-EUR",
"description":"Bitcoin/Euro",
"base":"BTC",
"size_precision":8,
"quote":"EUR",
"price_precision":2,
"market_order_price_slippage":"0.15",
"min_order_size":"0.0001",
"min_funds":"10"
}
]
}
```

The `size_precision` and `price_precision` fields indicate the maximum number of decimal places
allowed for order size and price, respectively. These precisions are enforced when placing
orders via the `/v1/orders` endpoint.

For example, if `size_precision` is 8 and `price_precision` is 2, an order with size
`0.00000001` and price `50000.00` would be valid, but an order with size `0.000000001`
or price `50000.001` would be rejected due to invalid precision.

This endpoint allows you to retrieve various statistics for all available markets.

Example response:
```json
{
"stats": [
{
"market": "BTC-EUR",
"last_price": "50000.0",
"open_24h": "48000.0",
"high_24h": "51000.0",
"low_24h": "47000.0",
"volume_24h": "100.0"
}
]
}
```

Field descriptions:
- `market`: The market identifier (e.g., "BTC-EUR").
- `last_price`: The last traded price in the market.
- `open_24h`: The opening price 24 hours ago.
- `high_24h`: The highest price in the last 24 hours.
- `low_24h`: The lowest price in the last 24 hours.
- `volume_24h`: The trading volume in the last 24 hours.
This endpoint allows you to retrieve the configuration details for a specific market by its identifier.

This endpoint allows you to retrieve a snapshot of the order book for a specific market by its identifier.

Example response:
```json
{
"timestamp": "1719354237834.784",
"bids": [[49999.0, 1.5], [49998.0, 2.0]],
"asks": [[50001.0, 1.0], [50002.0, 1.5]],
"event_id": 123456
}
```

Field descriptions:
- `timestamp`: The timestamp of the snapshot.
- `bids`: A list of bid prices and sizes.
- `asks`: A list of ask prices and sizes.
- `event_id`: The unique identifier for the snapshot event.

This endpoint allows you to retrieve the last tick (latest market data) for a specific market by its identifier.

Example response:
```json
{
"time": "1719354237834.784",
"ask": "50001.0",
"bid": "49999.0",
"volume": "100.0",
"price": "50000.0",
"size": "0.5"
}
```

Field descriptions:
- `time`: The timestamp of the last tick.
- `ask`: The last ask price.
- `bid`: The last bid price.
- `volume`: The trading volume.
- `price`: The last traded price.
- `size`: The size of the last trade.

This endpoint allows you to retrieve recent trades for a specific market by its identifier.

Example response:
```json
{
"trades": [
{
"time": "1719347541953",
"id": "12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789abc",
"price": "50000.0",
"size": "0.5",
"side": "buy"
}
]
}
```

Field descriptions:
- `id`: The unique identifier of the trade.
- `time`: The timestamp of the trade.
- `price`: The price at which the trade was executed.
- `size`: The size of the trade.
- `side`: The side of the order (e.g., "buy" or "sell").

200.description: Get recent trades for a market

get.description:
Requires `user:trading:read` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve a list of orders with various filters and pagination options:
- `limit`: The maximum number of orders to return (default is 100, range is 1 to 100).
- `before`: Cursor for pagination to get orders before a specific order ID.
- `market`: Filter orders by market.
- `status`: Filter orders by status.

post.description:
Requires `user:trading:write` permission

This endpoint allows you to place a new order in the specified market. You can place these types of orders:
- **Limit Order**: Requires `price` and `size`.
- **Market Order**: Requires either `size` or `funds`, but not `price`.

Example request for a limit order:
```json
{
"market": "btc_eur",
"side": "buy",
"size": 0.01,
"price": 100.0,
"type": "limit",
"post_only": false
}
```

delete.description:
Requires `user:trading:write` permission

This endpoint allows you to cancel all orders for the authenticated user's portfolio. Note that receiving a 204 response does not guarantee immediate cancellation; there may be a delay before all orders are fully cancelled.

get.description:
Requires `user:trading:read` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve detailed information about a specific order by its ID.

delete.description:
Requires `user:trading:write` permission

This endpoint allows you to cancel an existing order. Note that receiving a 200 response does not guarantee immediate cancellation; there may be a delay before the order is fully cancelled.

Example request:
```json
{
"order_id": "12345678-1234-1234-1234-123456789abc"
}
```

get.description:
Requires `user:trading:read` permission

This endpoint allows you to retrieve all account transactions associated with a specific order
by its ID.
This endpoint allows you to retrieve the profile information of the currently authenticated user.

ApiMarket.description:
Represents the different markets available for trading.

Each variant corresponds to a specific trading pair, such as BTC-EUR or ETH-CZK.

ApiOrderStatus.description:
Represents the status of an API order in the trading system.
- `Open`: The order has been placed into the orderbook. It may be partially filled but is still active.
- `Canceled`: The order was canceled before it could reach the orderbook.
- `Closed`: The order is no longer in the orderbook. It may have been fully or partially filled.

funds.description:
The total funds allocated for the order, if applicable (e.g., "5000.00").
- For limit orders: Never required.
- For market orders: Optional, but either `size` or `funds` must be provided.

post_only.description:
A flag indicating whether the order is post-only.
- Post-only orders are added to the order book only if they do not immediately match with an existing order.
- If a match is found upon placement, the order is canceled.

price.description:
The price at which the order is placed, if applicable (e.g., "5000.00").
- For market orders: Never required.
- For limit orders: Always required.

size.description:
The size of the order, indicating the amount to buy or sell (e.g., "1.0").
- For limit orders: Always required.
- For market orders: Optional.

MatchingStopReason.description:
Reasons why an order matching process was stopped.

### Variants
- `PostOnlyMatch`: The order was canceled because it would have matched immediately, violating the post-only condition.
- `SelfMatch`: The order was canceled to prevent self-trading.
- `UserRequest`: The order was canceled by user request.
- `NoLiquidity`: The order was canceled due to lack of liquidity in the market.
- `RestoreMatch`: The order was canceled to restore a previous state.
- `SlippageProtection`: The order was canceled to protect against price slippage.

OrderSide.description: Represents the side of an order in the market.

OrderType.description:
### Market Order
A market order is a buy or sell order to be executed immediately at the current market prices. As long as there are willing sellers and buyers, market orders are filled. Market orders are used when certainty of execution is a priority over the price of execution.

### Limit Order
A limit order is an order to buy a security at no more than a specific price, or to sell a security at no less than a specific price. This gives the trader control over the price at which the trade is executed; however, the order may never be executed.

TradeSide.description: Represents the side of an order in the market.

tags.name: Orders
tags.description: Place, cancel, and view orders on the exchange

tags.name: Snapshots
tags.description: Get point-in-time snapshots of market data

tags.name: Markets
tags.description: Get supported markets and trading pairs
